dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TANAKA (50) and old SAKAMOTO (late 60s but seems older; * weathered, bent) confer in whispers. SAKAMOTO’s wife, MOT (40) reclines, wrapped in a quilt. She is frail, her face etched with pain. She opens her eyes briefly to drink a medicinal tea: they are a silver color. In secret, her daughters CBIYO (9, clean-limbed, delicate and SATSU (15, slow, earthy) listen behind a make-shift screen. The TWO MEN continue in JAPANESE: *

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA .
dialogues.text: Have you made any provision for your daughters?

dialogues.speaker: SAKAMOTO
dialogues.text: (his head bowed in shame) * I've nothing left. Nothing. * Without understanding Japanese, we still comprehend the g situation. *

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA
dialogues.text: You're not young. Like this house. One good storm could carry you off. Satsu turns away, she cannot bear to hear more. But littl Chiye desperately presses her ear against the “wall's

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA

dialogues.text: I could never—-.

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: In the pelting rain, Sakamoto grimly lifts Chiyo into Tanaka's wooden cart, handing her to Satsu. in front, Tan takes the reins of the OX. Sakamoto lifts his lantern for final look as the cart pulls away. His old eyes fill with tears. . In Chiyo’s face, rainwater and sorrow stream together dow her face. The softly accented VOICE of 4 mature woman narrates in ENGLISH: ~ SAYURT’S VOICE A story like mine should never be told. Chiyo is jolted about in the back as Tanaka's fish-staine cart rattles over rough road. . SAYURI'S VOICE (cont‘d) For my world is as forbidden as it is fragile; without it’s mysteries, it cannot survive. Low-hanging branches whip the cart; Satsu pulis Chiyo clo to guard her from them. Tanaka urges the oxen onward. SAYURI'S VOICE (cont’d) My family lived in a tipsy house in a tiny village called Yoroido on the Sea of Japan. When I was born, my father was already old. My mother said he was like wood, as rooted to the earth as an old Sakura tree. But she and I were like water. Water doesn't stay in one place; it flows quickly-- The heavy oak wheels carve grooves through the mud. in th driving rain, they fill with water, which courses in rivu across the ground, tiny rivers. dialogues.text: Chill gray light. A coal-fired TRAIN ENGINE--like a great black DRAGON, belching smoke, with one malevolent white e idles on the platform. [Japanese sign: “Senzuru"].

dialogues.speaker: SAYURI'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I certainly wasn’t born to the life of a geisha. MEN load mailbacs, boxes of dried fish, sacks of rice. Fe passengers are boarding. On the platform weits MR. BEKKU (middle-aged, impersonal, coid). SAYURI‘S VOICE (cont'd) Like so much in my strange life, 1 was carried there, by the current. Tanaka greets Bekku, leaving Satsu and Chiyo huddled clos each other, shivering in their bare feet. They hold hande tightly. Tanaka makes the girls stand in front of Bekku:

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA
dialogues.text: Bow to Mr. Bekku. Satsu bows obedientiy, but Chiyo is too frightened; she j Stares at Bekku, dumbstruck. His heori (jacket) & kimono of smooth silk; his hands as soft as a woman's. TANAKA {cont ‘d) You too. Shaken out of her stupor, Chiyo bows. When she raises her head, Bekku notices her haunting silver eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BEKKU
dialogues.text: Hm. Curious eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: I have my mother’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BEKKU
dialogues.text: (to Tanaka) What are their names?

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA
dialogues.text: She's Chiyo. Her eister is Satsu. Bekku turns to Satsu and prods her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BERKKU
dialogues.text: They're sisters? She looks like a peasant next to this little one.

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA
dialogues.text: Their father does not want them to be separated. , Bekku hands him an envelope and both men bow. Tanaka touc the girls reassuringly, encouraging them: TANAKA (cont'd) Be good.  10 121 12 43 14 Als 15

dialogues.speaker: 1/6/05 DOUBLE GOLDENROD REVISION 7
dialogues.text: Gripping their elbows, Bekku propels Satsu and Chiyo into train car. Chiyo tries to twist free, calis to Tanaka:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Tanaka-san! Mr. Bekku jerks Chiyo on board.

dialogues.speaker: TANAKA
dialogues.text: (calling after them) Meta yo!.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The TRAIN winds through a megnificent vista of hilis and trees still stark with winter.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN WHEELS
dialogues.text: Sparks fly from the train brakes, and the SOUND of metal wheels scream agains metal tracks. INT./EXT. TRAIN STATION - MIYAKO. EVENING. [WINTER]. Bekku and hie two tiny warde disembark from the train. He ushers them through the bedlam of PASSENGERS, TRAIN OFFIC and BAGGAGE RANDLERS. Bekku puts Satsu and Chiyo in the RICKSHAW. He climbs in, wedging himself between Chiyo and Satsu. 10 il 12 a3 a4 Al5 15  J. 17 EXT: RICKSHAW MOVING - STREETS OF THE HANAMACHI. MIYAKO. NIGHT. [WINTER]. Chiyo keeps peeking past the huge form of Bekku, glimpsin passing buildings and brightly-lit electrical signs. POV image: A DISTINCTIVE TORII GATE spans the entrance to huge SHRINE, flanked by rows of HUGE WHITE PAPER LANTERNS They have crossed the winding river known as the Sonogawa they’re met by a crush of BICYCLES, HORSE-DRAWN CARTS, RICKSHAWS, and AUTOMOBILES. GROUPS of MEN in Western clothes and fedoras pass by the YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE, its wall hung with lanterns and theatr posters covered with Japanese & Chinese characters. Chiyo curiously cranes to see more but Bekku shoves her b and pins her firmly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Narrow streets are crowded with shuttered wooden facades the silhouettes of low tiled roofs. The darkness is punctuated by a few red lanterns in the near-distance.

dialogues.speaker: BEKKU
dialogues.text: Sokode. The rickshaw arrives at a wooden entrance gate. Bekku pul the girls from the rickshaw. He slides open the gate. Chiyo sees a lantern hanging ove wet stone courtyard, and beyond that, the entrance into a traditional Japanese okiya. The door is open: A mysterious female SILHOUETTE glides toward Chiyo, pause Her shape moves into the light of the lantern above the p revealing: HATSUMOMO (28), in full geisha regalia: Gorgeous kimono, sensuously-upswept hair studded with dangling hair orname A mask of pearl-white make-up sets off a blood-red mouth large almond-shaped eyes rimmed with fluid black. Behind her, AUNTIE (55) strikes a flint, “flinting” Hatsu for luck; SPARKS rain upon her back.  18 Bekku pushes the girls down onto the wet ground. Hatsumom steps imperiously past in her delicate sandals and pure w tabi (gloves for the feet]. As she ‘sweeps by, Chiyo turn her face up to watch: The geisha’s fluid kimono sleeves slowly lift like dreamy silken wings. She glides away like a butterfly of the nig Auntie moves to the girls, cane in hand. She walks with a slight limp, her hip jutting forward.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: These are the girls from Tanaka?

dialogues.speaker: BEKKU
dialogues.text: Sisters, yes, from Yoroido.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: (peers at Chiyo) This one maybe. The other one, no. Bekku roughly yanks Satsu back into the rickshaw.

dialogues.speaker: BEKKU
dialogues.text: Hayaku. The DRIVER pulls away. Chiyo rushes into the street. Crying, Satsu reaches out for her, but Auntie captures Ch The rickshaw flies on:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Satsu!

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: Chiyo-chan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auntie slides back a door to the okiya.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Show your respect for Mother. You must not speak; I will answer for you. (calling) Okasan!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: {from within) Come in!  10 Auntie pushes open ‘a shoji screen, revealing a dark room where a RADIO plays. Through spirals of smoke, Chiyo can a neatly-coiffed woman kneeling before accounting books, smoking a long traditional pipe: MOTHER (40s, business woman). Auntie grips Chiyo and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Kneel. And head down! Never look her in the face. Auntie shoves Chiyo's head down. Smoke streams from Mothe nose as she appraises the grubby child. She motions: Clos

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: She is Year of the Rooster.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Only nine? Mother makes: a dismissive sound and examines Chiyo‘’s di feet. She pulls up Chiyo’s dress to look at her straight legs; runs her thumb down Chiyo’s spine. Chiyo blurts:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Where is my sister? Auntie claps a hand over her mouth. Mother looks at Chiyo

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Let me see those eyes. Auntie stares. She hadn‘t noticed before. MOTHER (cont'd) Too much water.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: But Okasan, a little water is good, to guard against fire. You won’t have to worry about the okiya burning, and losing all your kimono. Mother considers this impassively. She gestures, Go on.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: These country girls. Too late to send her back now.  20 11

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER INSIDE THE OKIYA . 19
dialogues.text: Auntie pushes Chiyo up a step-tansu into the darkness of second floor. Chiyo notices a door ajar and peers inside. GRANNY reclines, an elderly figure with a balding crown a decayed teeth speckled with gold fillings; her skin yello and sagging. Her chin moves as she mumbles sutras under h breath. Chiyo recoils.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Mm. Yes. Granny. This used to be her okiya. Auntie leads Chiyo down a dark crooked passageway.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: What happened to her skin?

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: (by way of explanation) Lead. That old make-up was poison. Auntie pushes Chiyo up a few small steps -- INT: MAID’S ROOM. SECOND FLOOR. NIGHT. [WINTER] 20

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Keep her quiet. Mother is downstairs. -- to PUMPKIN (11, round-faced, comic.) Auntie shuts the door and Chiyo hears the bolt fall. She beats on the door

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Let me go! Let me go! She weeps as Pumpkin tries to pull her away --

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Shhh. Stop that. Mother will hear you; she’s got a bamboo stick.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: I want my sister! Pumpkin pulls Chiyo onto her futon, and muffles her sobs the quilt.  21 12

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: I cried, too, at first. You know, it is easier if you just forget everything that happened before you came to the okiya. If you impress Mother, and do exactly as she says-- (beaming at the possibility) --she will send you to school to be a geisha!

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: A geisha. Like Hatsumomo! You will get to drink sake, and sleep until noon. PUMPKIN grins encouragingly, and sticks her chest out. Sh wears two braids, pinned to her scalp. One sticks up, jaunty, like a stem. YOUNG PUMPKIN (cont‘d) (beat) I am Pumpkin. And an apt name it is, given her hairstyle.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Where is my sister?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Probably in another okiya in the Hanamachi. {with painful clarity) Your family sold you to this house. You live here now. As this sinks in, ON CHIYO’S FACE --

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Shivering, Chiyo (naked) squats on the stones near the privies, Auntie scrubs her feet with a hard brush. Mother hands Chiyo her dark tabi (socks) and geta (rough wood sandals.)  13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, you wear these. Outside, these. We don’t display our naked feet like monkeys. Next, Mother impatiently wraps Chiyo in a servant‘’s kimo

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Remember to always shut the shed door, so the rats don’t get in. If I ever find it open--even an inch-- it’s the bamboo stick for you. Now get to work. Be quiet! Hatsumomo is sleeping. (calling) Pumpkin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo scrubs the stepping stones while Pumpkin cleans the shed. Pumpkin explains in a whisper (which gets louder as she continues):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nights ago Hatsumomo had to stay at the tea-house until dawn, entertaining three Judges--and when she got home, she cried, “I‘m sooo tired!” And then she started-- (PUMPKIN makes a snoring sound) --and she knocked over a candle, and it singed her kimono and her futon started smoking, and Mother came in and said, “Pumpkin! You must stay awake, all night, so Hatsumomo doesn’t burn down the whole okiya!” (a breath, and then) When I am a geisha I will sleep as late as I want. I will wear a fancy kimono, and my hair will be in a split-peach!

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: A what? Pumpkin curls her tongue and sticks it out; it looks like “split peach.” Together, she and Chiyo giggle.  23 14

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Why can’t you be QUIET? Pumpkin freezes in terror. Even with tousled hair and smudged mascara, Hatsumomo is gorgeous. She spies CHIYO instantly, and gives her a long, slow appraisal. , HATSUMOMO (cont'd) So this ‘is the’ new arrival? A pity she still stinks of fish. She lights a cigarette casually and moves toward Chiyo. Mother steps. out onto the veranda: HATSUMOMO (cont ‘d) Hope you didn’t pay much for her, Mother. Not with those eyes. Water runs away. Mother dumps her tobacco ashes into a bin:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I pay too much for all of you. Mother leaves. Smiling, Hatsumomo bends down and tucks ba Chiyo’s hair, a sisterly gesture.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Stay out of my room. Your fingers smell; I can’t have you touching my things. Her fingers linger.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Pumpkin and Chiyo carry water from the well in the garden

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: When can I go outside?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Outside the okiya? You can’t. It’s not allowed. Carrying their buckets INSIDE, the girls climb the narrow fixed ladder that leads to the roof. Pumpkin climbs ahead

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: How will I find Satsu?  15

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: You can’t just walk up to every house in the Hanamachi. Do you know how many there are? CHIYO shakes her head “no.” YOUNG PUMPKIN (cont'd) ‘ Look. Pumpkin arrives on the roof and looks out over the Hanama [we don’t see yet]. Chiyo pulls herself up, sees with a j

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against a backdrop of softly rounded misty hills are THOUSANDS UPON THOUSANDS OF SLATE-BLUE TILED ROOFS so impenetrably close together, they seem almost to overlap. Pumpkin dumps her bucket into the water tank, splashing s on the tiles. Chiyo, crushed, stares at the maze of roofs INT. GRANNY’S ROOM - OKIYA. DAY. [WINTER]. 24 Chiyo carries a tray laden with food for Granny: rice and tiny white fishlings with dead, black eyes. She places it down in front of the old woman, who barks:

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY
dialogues.text: It is freezing! Close the window. Dutifully, Chiyo goes to the window and starts to pull it shut. Outside--on the street--she can’t help noticing: Hatsumomo, with a handsome young man; KOICHI (30s). With smile, he pulls her into a clandestine embrace. He kisses her neck, and whispers in her ear. Hatsumomo dissolves in girlish giggles. For a moment, Chiyo is absorbed by the sight of them. She snaps back to attention when she hears:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (VOICE)
dialogues.text: Chiyo! Chiyo yanks the window shut tightly. MOTHER (cont'd) Chiyo! Come quickly!  16 2 25 INT. HATSUMOMO‘S ROOM. DAY. [WINTER]. 25 Mother, cradling her ugly Japanese spaniel TAKU, slides o Hatsumomo’s door, revealing a room in disarray.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Hatsumomo is at the bath house. Tidy up.' '

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: But she made me promise--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Hatsumomo does not run this okiya. She gives Chiyo a sharp poke and Chiyo forces herself to into the room. Futon and quilts are piled in a tangled heap. Grimy white tabis and old wooden sushi boxes lie strewn among crumple tissues and spilled face powder and movie-photo magazines Chiyo leans down to pick up a box of powder; she does not hear Hatsumomo come in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, look who's in my room. Chiyo jumps up. Hatsumomo snatches up her dusting powder: HATSUMOMO (cont ’d) Did you touch this?? (sniffs, sarcastic) I can just hear the General now. “Why, Hatsumomo. You used to smell of jasmine; what’s this new perfume?” (wrinking her nose in distaste) “Blowfish?” (savagely) I told you never to touch my things! Can't you understand why?

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Because your General will say, “Hatsumomo, you stink.” Hatsumomo stares at her, displeased with her delivery.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: > At least you don’t smell as bad as your sister. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 17 HATSUMOMO (cont'd) You know she was here. She came by, looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: (stunned) What?

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: (ingenuous) ‘ Was I wrong to ask her to leave?

dialogues.speaker: CBRIYO
dialogues.text: (with poignant urgency) Please. Tell me where she is. Hatsumomo looks at her with a luminous smile.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Only if you swear yourself to me first. Yes? Now get out.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: The only reason Mother tolerates Hatsumomo is because she brings in good money. Auntie kneels amid a feast of colors, folding the many si kimono piled around her, then placing them neatly in lacquered boxes. Chiyo climbs a ladder and places the box in stacks along the walls. AUNTIE (cont’d) Never forget, it is Hatsumomo who pays for your supper. The clothes on your back. By the time she was twenty, she had already earned back her purchase price. Unheard of! She has. been the talk of the hanamachi ever since. Chiyo curious fingers one of the kimono:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: These are all hers? Auntie snatches the kimono away.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Certainly not. They belong to the okiya. (displays summer kimono) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 18 AUNTIE (cont'd) A kimono like this, made of Tatsumura silk? It would take a lifetime to earn! A Sea Captain had this made for Granny when she was only fourteen. Under Auntie’s deft folding, the exquisite embroidery disappears and the kimono goes into a red lacquered box: ‘AUNTIE (cont'd) A geisha needs an elegant wardrobe, just like an artist needs ink! If she is not properly dressed, then she is not a true geisha.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Nobody told me what a geisha is.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: You will find out soon enough. I have news for you, child. Chiyo looks at her, puzzled. AUNTIE (cont‘’d) ...Mother has determined. It is off to school with you. (beat) You are to become geisha. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. OKIYA
dialogues.text: Pumpkin’s feet hurry down the STEP-TANSU, Chiyo behind he The girls wear simple cotton school kimono. At the entrance of the okiya, Pumpkin hops into her shoes Mother unfastens the bolt on the gate and hurries Pumpkin Chiyo through:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Quick. Quick. For the first time since her arrival, Chiyo steps into th street. Pumpkin yanks her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumpkin and Chiyo run down the street, wooden geta clatte on the paving stones.  19

dialogues.speaker: SONOGAWA
dialogues.text: The girls race across a bridge that spans the flowing Sonogawa, gracefully overhung with bare-limbed cherry tre Chiyo’s head swivels at TWO MAIKO walking past, their hai fashioned in the traditional split-peach style. Pumpkin grins, and points at them. Once again, she curls her tong into a “split peach.” Together she and Chiyo laugh. Pumpkin pulls Chiyo after h into a tunnel --

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Hurry! As they run, Pumpkin jumps up to touch a low-hanging FISH CARVING and make it swing; a child‘s ritual. She races do a jumbled alley toward the theatre. Suddenly, Chiyo break rank:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: {with resolve) Pumpkin! I’m sorry; I‘m going to run-- I’m going to find Satsu-- This makes PUMPKIN stop, cold.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: No! Chiyo, don't! (beat) You will ruin your own chances, and mine too! Please. Stay with me! Pumpkin notices a morsel of food in the gutter. She gives cry of discovery in Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Mite, mite! To Chiyo's disbelief, Pumpkin squats down and snatches up dirty skewer of food fallen from a vendor's cart. She tak a bite: PUMPKIN (cont'd) Mm, squid! Pumpkin pulls Chiyo into --  29 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls race along walkways to the school’s entrance, Pumpkin still chewing the squid -- ‘ YOUNG PUMPKIN (CONT’D) If you are not careful, Mother will toss you back onto the street, and then what? You will wind up with your obi tied in front.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: “In front?”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: You know. A prostitute. Because they spend so much time on their backs.

dialogues.speaker: CEIYO
dialogues.text: What is a “prostitute”? * Pumpkin doesn’t reply but climbs a wall of cubby holes li ladder and puts her sandals at the top. Chiyo follows. Pumpkin jumps down and grabs a shingle from the basket by entry and hangs it on the wall among HUNDREDS OF NAMES. Chiyoe tries to read them, but Pumpkin pulls her away:

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Look for your sister later!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. GEISHA SCHOOL. DAY.
dialogues.text: As Chiyo and Pumpkin race to class. They run by a row of 6 MAIKO, who go through precise danc movements as the FEMALE TEACHER (elegant, older) beats ti with her folded fan, calling out the steps in Japanese. A silver-haired GEISHA beats a tsuzumi. Pumpkin and Chiyo cut through the school garden past a TE CEREMONY CLASS (5 Geisha) and a CALLIGRAPHY CLASS (6 Maik led by one female teacher.). They pass a tatami room where 5 GEISHA play the shamisen by a MALE TEACHER, and enter: A classroom where a ragged line of 8 YOUNG GIRLS in cotto kimono try to follow a weary FEMALE TEACHER. A STUDENT kneels by a small Victorela, winding the scratchy recordi  31

dialogues.speaker: 10/14/04 PINK REVISION 21
dialogues.text: The Teacher barks out the steps in Japanese, hitting the girls with her fan. Pumpkin and Chiyo dart into line at the back of the room, the Teacher bears down upon them, smacking her fan as she shouts out the time in cadence:

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: You - are - late! The Teacher whacks Pumpkin with her fan, keeping time, as Pumpkin tries clumsily to perform the steps and Chiyo tri to follow. The Teacher shoves the shoji door closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Chiyo kneels, trying to stay awake as she practice her shamisen. The sound of raucous LAUGHTER:

dialogues.speaker: KORIN
dialogues.text: Sssh, Hatsumomo-san, you’1ll wake the entire house. Hatsumomo and her geisha friend KORIN (20s) arrive drunk giggling. Korin spies Chiyo: KORIN (cont‘d) Your big sister is thirsty. So am I. Go get us some beer.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: I’m not in the mood for beer.

dialogues.speaker: KORIN
dialogues.text: I know what you're in the mood for, and his name is Koichi. Hatsumomo flares; she doesn't want Korin to give away her secret:

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: What did you say? *

dialogues.speaker: KORIN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I forgot -- *

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: You’re just jealous someone cares for me!  22

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Hatsumomo opens a package wrapped in silk. She spreads ou ivory colored, embroidered kimono.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Guess who this belongs to? ‘ ' Hatsumomo wets an ink block: HATSUMOMO (cont'd) I will give you a clue. A geisha as desired as she is...ought to keep a close eye on her clothes!

dialogues.speaker: KORIN
dialogues.text: It‘s Mameha’s?? How did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Bribed her maid. She laughs, enjoying her own cleverness. Hatsumomo dips a calligraphy brush, and gives it to Korin. Korin begins giggling; she has a failure of nerve:

dialogues.speaker: KORIN
dialogues.text: Oh I can’t. I can’t. (eyeing Chiyo) Give it to her. She thrusts the brush back at Hatsumomo. Hatsmomo smiles Chiyeo, who shrinks back. Hatsumomo grabs Chiyo's wrist a forces the brush into her hand, points to a place on the kimono --

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: There. Chiyo hesitates. Their eyes lock: HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Remember? You swore yourself to me. Chiyo reluctantly takes up the brush. HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Now then, little Chiyo. It’s time to practice your calligraphy.  33 34 35 23 Hatsumomo points to a place on the kimono. Chiyo touches brush to the milky fabric, leaving a smear of heavy black ink. Korin giggles. Hatsumomo glares at Chiyo as if to sa “Again.” Chiyo wets her brush a second time. EXT. MAMEHA‘S APARTMENT BUILDING NEAR THE SONOGAWA. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatsumomo and Korin huddle with Chiyo in the shadows:

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Do not let anybody see you. Chiyo walks quickly and leaves the folded kimono at the d A figure opens the door, flooding Chiyo’s face with light Chiyo sees a beautiful woman--MAMEHA (29)--whose long lon glossy hair flows over a nearly transparent kimono. Their eyes meet. Chiyo runs blindly --

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Gripping Chiyo, Mother pours a bucket of water over her b and begins severely lashing her with a bamboo rod.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Thieving rat! That kimono was worth more than you!

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Careful, Okasan! You will hurt yourself more than her. Let me. Auntie seizes the rod and Mother walks back into the Okiy

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Kneel. Chiyo kneels, weeping, ashamed. Auntie painfully lowers h twisted hip and sits on the stone step. AUNTIE (cont'd) What have you done to Hatsumomo? Chiyo looks up tearfully.  36 37 24 ’ CHIYO I haven't done anything, I promise you. :

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Whatever you've done to anger her, you'd be wise to stop. Now. . (when Chiyo is silent) You would like 'Hatsumomo to be your big sister, wouldn’t you? Then you must learn to please her. (beat) Lie face down. Chiyo obeys. Auntie gets to her feet painfully, favoring hip. AUNTIE (cont'd) When I was young, Granny was Mother of this okiya. One day I was naughty, speaking out of turn, as you often do. Granny whipped me so fiercely, I was crippled. And so I never becamé a geisha. I could never repay my debt. Auntie’s rod comes down, swish! AUNTIE (cont'd) And so everyone in the okiya suffered. Another swish! Chiyo suffers the beating stoically. AUNTIE (cont'd) (when Chiyo complies) I will beat you “just so.” To spare you the agony I have endured. Swish!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE OKIYA
dialogues.text: Mother listens with satisfaction, then turns up the radio

dialogues.speaker: BACK GARDEN
dialogues.text: Auntie walks away, leaving Chiyo sobbing on the ground. Chiyo hears the veranda shoji open. Hatsumomo lounges against her door with a sly smile. She is drinking sake.  38 39 25

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: I told you not to let anybody see you. , Chiyo turns on her with tears of pain:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: I have kept my promise. So tell me. Where is she? Hatsumomo licks the rim of sake cup, then puts it down. S reaches out to Chiyo, cradling the child’s hands in her o

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: She's in the next hanamachi in a house called Tatsuyo. (beat) Trust me, little Chiyo. You will find her. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: RAIN sheets from tile roofs. WATER rushes along the stree as in a stream, overflowing the curbstones. INT. HATSUMOMO’S ROOM. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. 39 Hatsumomo stands in her wig cap, looking wan except for vibrant red lips. A cigarette dangles from her mouth. Mr. BEKKU forcefully tugs back her obi ties. Hatsumomo bridle and hisses:

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Tighter! And BEKKU gives another fierce yank. The sound of Hatsumomo’s sharp little cry stops Chiyo, who peeks throu the doorway. Hatsumomo catches Chiyo’s face in the mirror HATSUMOMO (cont'd) Chiyo! You will walk me to the Yukimoto teahouse, won't you? They lock eyes; a private communique sizzles between them HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Then you will stand and wait for me?  41 42 43 44 45 46 26 EXT. HANAMACHI STREETS. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. They set out, Chiyo, shivering, holding a scarlet oiled-p umbrella high over Hatsumomo as she lifts her kimono abov the puddles. EXT: YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. Rain batters down. Chiyo, soaked to the bone, waits under scant shelter of the red umbrella. EXT: YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. {WINTER]. The tea room’s front doors are open slightly to the courtyard. Through a decorative screen, we glimpse for th first time the hidden teahouse world:

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: A simple room with handsome golden screens and warm, bric red walls, polished dark wood. Hatsumomo and TWO OTHER GEISHA kneel before a GROUP OF MEN seated at low portable tables, pouring sake. Laughing and smiling, Hatsumomo loo the part of a perfect geisha, the very soul of beauty and wit. EXT, YUKIMOTO TEAHOUSE COURTYARD. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. The red umbrella sits open on the ground in the front courtyard garden, abandoned. Rain pours in torrents. EXT. PATH ALONG THE RIVER. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. CLOSE ON CHIYO’S FEET RUNNING as her wooden sandals pound sure-footedly along the river path, splashing through puddles. EXT: NIGHT STREETS IN THE NEXT HANAMACHI. NIGHT. RAIN. {WINTER]. Chiyo runs past DRUNKEN MEN into seedier streets: EXT: THE SEEDY PART OF TOWN. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. The rundown “teahouses” in this hanamachi look different the elegant Yukimoto. 40 42 43 44 45 46  a7 27 Here, the roof tiles are crooked and broken. Under cracke lanterns, WOMEN huddle in doorways and sit lined up behin barred windows, their white faces and red lips crudely painted. . Chiyo speaks to a WOMAN in a doorway. The Woman points, gives Chiyo directions. Chiyo hurries on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo yanks on a wooden door, knocking as hard as she can Finally a small panel slides open. An OLD CRONE looks out

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Satsu. The panel snaps shut. Chiyo beats on the door, to no avai CHIYO (cont'd) Satsu! From Yoroido! Satsu! Chiyo stands uncertainly, soaked to the skin, her hair an thin kimono plastered to her body. She casts around helplessly, and sees: From a dark side doorway, a MAN in Western clothes depart Behind him in the shadows, Chiyo can see a young woman; h silhoutte is familiar. Chiyo calls: CHIYO (cont‘d) Satsu? Satsu! Satsu edges into the lantern’s crimson glow and Chiyo rac to her.

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: Chiyo-chan! They embrace but something is in the way. Chiyo realizes: Satsu’s cumbersome obi is tied in front. SATSU (cont'd) What took you so long--

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: --But Satsu, I tried--

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: (recriminatory) I went to your okiya weeks ago! They laughed, and turned me away---

dialogues.speaker: 12/21/04 DOUBLE YELLOW REVISION 28
dialogues.text: Chiyo sees in the light: Satsu’s face is marred by a beat

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: -Please, I did not know--

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: I thought you'd forgotten me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satsu, no--I could never--

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: I've missed you so much--

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Let's leave--tonight--

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: But we’ll need money, Chiyo--I know where I can steal some, first thing tomorrow--

dialogues.speaker: . CHIYO
dialogues.text: No, please--~tonight--

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Meet me at the Sasame bridge. As soon as it’s dark-- A sudden sound; the front door opens. Footsteps. Satsu's face fills with alarn. SATSU (cont ‘d) Now I have to go--quickly, before someone catches us-- Chiyo, trembling, desperately clings to Satsu as her eyes fill with tears. Satsu pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: What if I cannot get away?

dialogues.speaker: SATSU
dialogues.text: Be there, Chiyo. It's our one chance. Once I’ve left I can‘t go back. I’ve waited as long as I can. WNow--go! Satsu disappears into the house.  29 EXT. FRONT ENTRANCE AND BACK GARDEN - OKIYA. NIGHT. RAIN. [WINTER]. Chiyo tries the gate - it slides open. Chiyo hesitates at the entrance of the okiya, and then sl quietly around the side, via the narrow passage. ' In the back garden, Chiyo moves covertly toward the kitch and the back door - but she hears a NOISE and sees: In the STORAGE ROOM, the heavy door has been left ajar. Chiyo hears the rustle of mice burrowing into bags of ric inside. She hastens to close the door -- -- and sees inside the dark room something strange and fascinating: Hatsumomo is lying under a man. It is Hatsumomo’s boyfriend KOICHI (30, handsome). Koichi spies Chiyo and leaps to his feet. —

dialogues.speaker: KOICHI
dialogues.text: What is she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KOICHI
dialogues.text: She’s seen us. Hatsumomo’s stricken by his words. Koichi gropes among th rice bags for his sash, dressing hastily. Hatsumomo grabs Chiyo:

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Stupid girl! In the okiya, a light comes on. HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Why have you come back? The perfect chance to escape... They freeze as they hear Taku start barking madly inside. KOICHI finishes pulling on his clothes. HATSUMOMO (cont‘d) Koichi, please--

dialogues.speaker: KOICHI
dialogues.text: Look at us, sneaking around like criminals--  30

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Koichi, don’t--

dialogues.speaker: KOICHI
dialogues.text: It’s degrading. They hear hurrying footsteps and Mother’s voice calling: MOTHER’S VOICE What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: (to KOICHI) Go! Now! Koichi ducks out the side path -- just as Mother and bark Taku appear at the tatami room door onto the veranda:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Show your face! Hidden in hér obi, Hatsumomo finds some money. Thinking fast, she stuffs the bills inside Chiyo’s kimono. Mother- bamboo stick in hand--halts at the sight of Chiyo and Hatsumomo in front of the store room. Taku is barking int the dark, toward the narrow side path. Auntie has come ou in her night kimono.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Look! Okasan! I caught her. She was running away with her sister, the whore. Hatsumomo snatches Chiyo’s kimono open. Money spills out. Mother whirls on Chiyo and begins beating her.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You little thief! Chiyo, terrified, finally breaks her silence --

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: No! She is lying!

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: --after all we have done for her--

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: --I saw her with a man--right there (the “bed” of rice bags) - His name is Koichi!  49 50 31

dialogues.speaker: SHUT UP
dialogues.text: Mother stops abruptly, stares at Hatsumomo, seeing the tr

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You shut up. Take her arms. In the pouring rain, Auntie seizes her arms; Hatsumomo gi a startled cry. Mother reaches under Hatsumomo’s kimono a parts her legs. Mother withdraws her hand, smells her fingers. Hatsumomo chokes back a defiant tear. Her face i crimson, Mother slaps Hatsumomo hard, making her gasp. MOTHER (cont‘d) You are never to see him again. Her make-up running, Hatsumomo glares at Chiyo with full loathing. MOTHER (cont’d) Bolt the gate. No one is leaving this okiya. Chiyo’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. OKIYA.
dialogues.text: Auntie rolls the heavy front door shut with a klunk! INT/EXT. VERANDA & BACK GARDEN OF OKIYA. DUSK. [WINTER]. The rain has stopped; water drains from the tiled roof an rushes in the garden's gutter. Chiyo crouches low, scouri the stepping stones. She glances at the sundial in the garden; the light siants long across it. It's late. She looks anxiously toward the sky, and can see the moon, starting to reveal itself on the horizon. Night is approaching. Chiyo rises, and her heart swells in her chest; it’s time make her escape, but how? She glances to and fro, just as MOTHER passes through the garden, and tosses her a recriminatory look. It makes Chiyo cower, and she sinks b down, scrubbing the stones with renewed fervor. Satisfied MOTHER disappears. A few drops of water from above fall onto Chiyo’s face. S wipes them away. A few more drops fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 52 53 32 She looks up and notices that the water is coming from th chain of verdigris bells that hang from the gutter. With eyes she follows the path of the gutter up to-- The roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo steps out onto the’ roof by the water tank. She see The maze of tiled roofs. Stepping out on her wooden sandal, Chiyo tests her weight the roof tiles. Her wet shoe skids on the rain-slick tile and comes out from under her. Chiyo fails on her bottom h and barely saves herself from tumbling down the slope. Her shoe falls, clattering down the tiles and plummeting the edge into the garden, The noise sets off Taku’s barki (0.S.). Chiyo gathers her courage. She takes off her other wooden shoe and leaves it perched on the ridge of the okiya’s ro Chiyo inches, half sliding, down the sloping tiles to the edge of the roof, which is adjacent to the NEXT OKIYA’S r EXT. BACK GARDEN & PRIVIES. CONTINUOUS. NIGHT. [WINTER]. Taku barks hysterically, running around and around Chiyo’ fallen shoe, sounding the alarm. EXT: NEXT OKIYA‘S ROOF. CONTINUOUS. NIGHT. [WINTER]. 53 Chiyo gathers her courage and jumps -- She falls onto the NEXT OKIYA’S SLOPING ROOF (#2). Her ba feet slip and scramble for purchase. Then her fingers gri the wet tiles, and one foot wedges safely against a tile. Chiyo scrambles across the roof and swings her legs over ridge cap. She slowly lets herself skid down the low slop and at the bottom, and sees: A gap between her and NEXT O (#3). Taku‘s barking sounds farther away. Chiyo crouches at the edge, her toes curling over the til edge. She pushes off, drops to the NEXT ROOF (#3), catche her balance: Safe. Chiyo clambers up this even steeper slope (#3). Hand over hand, she climbs to the top; she seems to be gaining strength. Her hand grasps the cap tiles. The tiles hold.  54 33 Chiyo reaches up with her other hand. Now both hands safe grip the cap tiles. Her fingers tighten as she hauls hers up. She can see the NEXT OKIYA’S ROOF (#4), and beyond th the tangle of electrical wires on a pole and red lanterns the street -- Freedom. The cap tiles (#3) give way with a clatter. Chiyo skids helter-skelter down the long wet slope of the roof. She screams — ‘ Her chin knocks against a tile, hard, jerking her head ba STARS pinwheel in the NIGHT SKY --

dialogues.speaker: AN ACCOUNTING BOOK
dialogues.text: With a fine-point brush, Mother makes a notation in her accounting book on her desk. A MALE DOCTOR leaves. Pumpkin sees him out and closes Mother's door. Chiyo lies on a futon, her arm is bandaged, her chin cut. Mother impassively adds up figures in her accounting book

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Dr. Moro is very expensive. You seem to be racking up quite a debt. (ticks down the column) Kimono, destroyed. Geisha school. Rice and pickles, train ticket, Mr. Bekku - all this on top of the money I paid Mr. Tanaka, and for what? The two most worthless girls in Japan! (makes an entry) And now I hear that your sister has run away. I will have to return the money Mrs. Tatsuyo paid for her. That is quite a sum.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should send me home.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (with a harrumph) Who can I send you home to?  55 34 Mother goes to her tansu and takes out a cloth-wrapped object. She unwraps two black lacquered tablets with gold letters. Chiyo recognizes them at once. MOTHER (cont'd) These came weeks ago from Mr. Tanaka. Mother leaves them. Auntie picks up the accompanying lett

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: “Dear Satsu and Little Chiyo: As one who was once an orphaned child myself, this humble person is sorry to inform you that six weeks after you left for your new life in Miyako, the suffering of your honored mother came to its end--” Chiyo's face fills with tears. AUNTIE (CONT'D) (cont'd) “--and only a few weeks afterward your honored father departed this world as well. This humble person feels confident both your honored parents have found their places in paradise.” Chiyo picks up each tablet in turn, clasping them tightly her breast. AUNTIE (cont'd) “But happily--in the okiya--your own future is assured.” Auntie’s voice as she reads the letter fades, and is supplanted by another:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You will never be a geisha. You are too head-strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her arm bandaged and wearing rags, Chiyo cleans all the household shoes; all around her are dozens of sandals. MOTHER’S VOICE (0.S.) If I could sell off your bones to pay back all that you owe, I'd rip them right out of your body.  56 57 58 35 Mother drops her bundled school items and her shamisen, t returned,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exterior wall displays ROWS OF SPRING FESTIVAL POSTER Branches of blooming CHERRY hang over the walkways of the school, but Chiyo walks by them without seeing.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You will pay back the okiya another way: as a drudge,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo places her wrapped shamisen and her school clothes books at the open classroom door: MOTHER’S VOICE (0.S.) Each week, a few coins, and maybe-- Maybe--by the end of your life, your debt will be paid. Inside, a group of 6 beautifully-costumed young MATKO (le a female teacher) rehearse for the “Spring Dances” with paddies of willow and cherry blossoms. Four other MAIKO w their turn. Chiyo notes the MAIKO without emotion; she knows now that this world is closed to her forever.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Chiyo pauses on the bridge, tears streaming. WEEPING CHER TREES drop their blossoms in the stream; the blossoms flo away on the water’s gentle surface. Chiyo watches them, yearning. CHAIRMAN‘’S VOICE It is too pretty a day to be so unhappy. She looks up into the broad face and compassionate eyes o THE CHAIRMAN (34). He is handsome and graceful. He notice her cut chin and bandaged arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you fall down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo is too shy to answer. The Chairman crouches which brings them face te face. Chiyo ducks her head rather tha meet his eyes. . CHAIRMAN (cont ‘d) Why so shy? Nothing to be ashamed of; we all stumble from time to time. He offers her handkerchief, and--embarrassed--she dabs he face. The Chairman gestures toward the most beautiful of three geisha in his company. CHAIRMAN (cont'd) You see that enchanting lady in pink? Once--when she was just a maiko--she fell clean off her okobo. When The Geisha laughs in response, it borders on music.

dialogues.speaker: GEISHA
dialogues.text: It's true; I did.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: And now look at her; so elegant.

dialogues.speaker: GEISHA
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, shouldn‘t we hurry? We'll miss the beginning. Bowing, Chiyo would back away, excusing herself, but the Chairman stops her with a gentle hand. He shrugs at the geisha:

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: We see the Spring Dances every year. We can spare a moment. The geisha turn inward, twittering among themselves. The Chairman turns to Chiyo. CHAIRMAN (cont‘d) What’s your name? She doesn't respond. CHAIRMAN (cont'd) Don’t be afraid to look at me. Someone has been cruel to you. Or perhaps life has been cruel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: None of us find as much kindness in this world as we should. © (and then) Do you like sweet plum, or cherry?

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: You mean - to eat? . I ‘ The Chairman laughs and leads Chiyo toward the footpath t goes along the stream, where a VENDOR sells shaved ice.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: I like sweet plum myself. {to the vendor) Both kinds. Chiyo hungrily watches the Vendor put a scoop of lurid pi into a paper cup. The Chairman hands it to her: CHAIRMAN (cont‘d) I wait for these every spring. Chiyo takes her first bite; when she pulls the cup away f her lips, they’re stained with color. She smiles coyly.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Now I'm a geisha, too. The CHAIRMAN laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: And so you are! As they take bites of their ices, Chiyo absorbs him with wonder. CHAIRMAN (cont'd) How did you come by such surprising eyes?

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: My mother gave them to me.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Generous of her, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: As you have been to me.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Smile for me, won't you?  59 60 38 Chiyo can’t help it; she does. CHAIRMAN (cont'd) There now. That is your gift to me. He wraps some coins in his handkerchief and tucks it into hand. , CHAIRMAN (cont'd) This will buy your supper. Now promise me one thing. Next time you take a tumble...no frowns. He smiles back at her, and she nods. Chiyo watches the Chairman walk away toward the geisha who await him; they their arms around him, like butterfly wings, and he seems disappear. Chiyo stares after them longingly, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Chiyo runs through the Hanamachi, on a mission.

dialogues.speaker: SAYURI'S VOICE
dialogues.text: In that moment I changed from a girl facing nothing but emptiness -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo continues to run through a corridor of huge broad orange torii gates that meander far up a wooded hillside. SAYURI‘S VOICE (CONT’D) ~ to someone with purpose. I saw that to be a geisha could be a stepping stone to something else. Chiyo arrives at the SHRINE and stretches up to reach the huge bell cords. She pulls the ropes and claps three time SAYURI'S VOICE (cont'd) The money he had given me could have bought fish and rice for a month. But I gave it back in prayer. She opens the handkerchief: The Chairman’s coins. Chiyo drops the coins in the offering box and bows. She kneels:  61 62 39 SAYURI'S VOICE (cont'd) I asked one day to be worthy of the chairman's world...to meet him again...and to become a geisha. Cherry blossoms blow past the serene altar of the shrine become SNOWFLAKES. 1 .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNOW blows around the eaves of the shuttered okiyas, and fills the ridges of the tiled roofs of the Hanamachi. We hear a tinny RADIO, reporting the news about Japan’s w with Russia and Allied and Axis powers battling in Europe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older Bekku straps Pumpkin (16) into her obi, grunting Pumpkin gives cries of discomfort as he pulls the cords e tighter. She hollers up the tansu steps:

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Chiyo! Did you find my comb yet?

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: Here, let me. Chilly adult BARE FEET appear, pattering down the cramped stairs, as Chiyo (15) hurries to obey. As she descends, w see she’s graceful even in a maid's rags; she wears a servant's long braid. Chiyo hastens to Pumpkin, ornamenta comb in hand.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Arigato. I couldn‘t sleep! I was so worried about my stupid hair! (with dread) Am I lopsided? Chiyo art-fully wedges the comb into Pumpkin‘’s maiko hairstyle, and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: You look beautiful. Pumpkin gives her a grateful smile. They briefly, covertl clasp hands. Then Mother appears with Auntie (both dresse for the occasion) and the girls‘ hands come apart. MOTHER scrutinizes Pumpkin'’s rounded hairstyle, the haircomb sticking out at a jaunty angle:  63 64 40

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: With your hair like that, you look more like a Pumpkin than ever! Don’t poke your neck forward like a tortoise! -- as she plucks at Pumpkin with critical tweaks. Chiyo i all but invisible; Bekku absently kicks her aside. ‘ Hatsumomo appears, impossibly beautiful in a flamboyant kimono.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: She is not ready? We will be late! Pumpkin takes her in, dismayed. Bekku laughs:

dialogues.speaker: BEKKU
dialogues.text: Poor Pumpkin - Her debut, and everyone will be staring at you.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: This time - tune your shamisen before you play. When you make a fool of yourself, it is your Big Sister who gets the blame. (re: Pumpkin‘s tears) Stop crying! Your face will run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO RICKSHAWS (the first carrying Hatsumomo and Pumpkin, second-Mother and Auntie) disappear into the veil of swir snowfall. Chiyo turns back sadly. By the door she sees: Pumpkin’s shamisen._ Chiyo grabs it, looks down at her bare feet. Chiyo snatch up Auntie’s garden clogs ~~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying the bundled shamisen, Chiyo runs in Auntie'’s ga clogs, down the snowy streets, over the frozen Sonogawa. Delicate icicles hang from the barren weeping-cherry tree  66 68 41

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: The Yukimoto TEAHOUSE OWNER (female) takes the bundled shamisen from Chiyo. The door slides shut on Chiyo. She hesitates --

dialogues.speaker: BACK GARDEN OF YUKIMOTO
dialogues.text: Chiyo slips around to the back garden, hoping for a glimp of Pumpkin’s debut. The closed shojis encased by an outside layer of glass pa present a blank face to the verandas. Chiyo can hear LAUGHTER and VOICES, BOTTLES CLINKING. Curious, Chiyo steps stealthily onto the veranda. A filigreed iron lantern lights the snowy stone step. The glass panel is open a very tiny crack. Chiyo quietly slid it open and passes through. She sneaks up to the shoji screen and crouches. Chiyo wets her finger and presses it the paper of the screen creating a tiny transparent circl Chiyo peeks through:

dialogues.speaker: INT. YUKIMOTO TEAROOM. NIGHT.
dialogues.text: In the warmly-lit room, eight or more WELL-DRESSED MEN si lacquered tables waited upon by Hatsumomo, Korin. The men applaud as Pumpkin sings and plays the shamisen.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE TEAROOM
dialogues.text: A CLIENT notices a SILHOUETTE on the shoji. Someone is on the veranda. Curious, he alerts men on either side of him

dialogues.speaker: BACK GARDEN OF YUKIMOTO
dialogues.text: Chiyo strains to see more-- Pumpkin has gone out of view. The shoji suddenly flies open: It is The Chairman, inches from her, face to face. Chiyo knows him at once, It takes her breath away. The light from the tearcom falls directly on Chiyo and he distinctive silver-gray eyes. She looks ethereal. The Chairman is halted, perhaps by her beauty, perhaps by memory - but in that moment as he stares at her, time sto  69 70 71 72 42 Chiyo reflexively bolts. Other Clients, amused, walk out onto the veranda. The Chairman, stands in the garden, oblivious to the snow fal on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MALE SERVANT sweeping the front steps catches sight of Chiyo as she runs to the front gate. The Teahouse-owner orders him to follow the stranger. He drops his snow broo and races after her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: With the Male Servant calling behind her, Chiyo runs into street, her wooden geta slipping on the ice. Chiyo yanks the shoes and runs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo ducks into a dark nook and lets the RUNNING FOOTSTE go past. When they are gone, from inside her kimono Chiyo takes something she has kept pressed against her heart: SAYURI’S VOICEOVER The winter that I turned fifteen, Fate brought me three things: I saw the Chairman again. Chiyo’s cold fingers caress the Chairman’s finely embroid handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone figure in black with a black parasol glides throug the white tempest, down a narrow street toward the okiya. SAYURI’S VOICEOVER (CONT ’D) Granny left us. And most surprising of all....  73 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slender gloved hand reaches up to ring the gate’s bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother notices a mysterious stranger at the front gate.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Quick Chiyo, put up the screen. (to herself) Why is she here? Mother picks up Taku and disappears. Chiyo grabs the scre and rushes to obscure Pumpkin, who’s sitting, scooping ri into her mouth. Auntie barks:

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: (to Chiyo) Open the gate! Chiyo runs to the entry. 73 74

dialogues.speaker: 74B
dialogues.text: +e FOF + * oF  75 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo sees Mameha, and crumples inside with fear (the rui kimono!). She bows low to hide her face, as Mameha steps of her sandals and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, tightly-coiffed and in a somber colors, bows as Auntie leads Mameha into Mother’s room & office. Her desk set up with pen and paper and abacus. Auntie closes the door & instantly puts her ear to the cr Pumpkin’s all ears, too. Chiyo grabs a rag and begins to polish the floor by Mother's door. She, Auntie and Pumpki crane to hear:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mameha-san, I know that you would never joke at an old lady's expense- Auntie inches the door open more, and the voices are clea

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: I was only thinking on your behalf...Now that your beloved Granny is gone, you have no need for a maid--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: But Chiyo?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Just think how she would enrich your okiya!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I have to tell you...she is unusually stupid. (beat) And her debt...!

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: A geisha returns her investment faster than a maid. Chiyo whispers to Pumpkin, incredulous:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Are they really talking about me?  45 Y Pumpkin, nods, equally stunned. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I would never question the great Mameha. But you could choose anyone in the Hanamachi--

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: You flatter me, truly--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: --I'd give you my Pumpkin, if she were not already tied to Hatsumomo--

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: ~-please, I would never dream of asking--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Besides, I can always sell Chiyo to Mrs. Tatsuyo. ” MAMEHA But with your eye for beauty and your nose for talent...surely you ) can see what a terrible waste that would be!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: If you were not the kind-hearted geisha I know you to be...then I might think you were dishonest. (beat) Even conniving.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I might think you were scheming against Hatsumomo.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEBA
dialogues.text: Then I’m grateful, Mrs. Nitta, that you don’t have a suspicious mind.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Perhaps you can pique my interest with-~

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: --your offer?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: (brass tacks now ) I will cover Chiyo’s schooling. All of. her expenses. Till after her debut. ‘

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Now I’m confident you are teasing--

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: I could not be more sincere. If Chiyo hasn't repaid her debt within six months after her debut--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Impossible! Too little time!

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: (resolutely) ~-then I will pay you twice over. 2 Mother is astonished by the proposal -- but not more astonished than Pumpkin and Chiyo in the hallway:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Why, no Geisha could ever-~

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: You see? I am willing to assume all the risk.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mameha-san, you might as well toss your money away!

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: I am certain you will not object to one, trivial condition...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: If Chiyo erases her debt in the time allowed...you will have no part in her future earnings.  77 47

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mameha-san! My respect for you is too great...too vast...to allow you to make such a foolish wager. (clearly accepting her:) Let me fetch the account books. Chiyo drops her polishing rag and darts away. Pumpkin div back into her morning rice bowl. Auntie picks up the rag pretends to polish the door frame as Mother appears. Moth gives Auntie a look as she retrieves her books. INT. GRANNY’S OLD ROOM - THE OKIYA. DAY. [WINTER] 77

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It’s too good to be true. Mameha is up to something. Mother & Auntie draw the bamboo shade and open the window Granny’s dusty old room. They begin moving Granny’s thing out of what will now become CHIYO’S ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: AUNTIE
dialogues.text: She is not in it for the money, that much is for certain. Rumor has it--ever since the Prime Minister bought her mizuage--she has been rich! They say he paid a record sum.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Is that so? Chiyo undresses behind a simple cotton kimono that Pumpki holds open, changing out of servant's rags. She whispers:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: "Mizuage”? Pumpkin biushes and gestures with her hand: I_can‘t say. Hatsumomo pauses at the doorway:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Absurd to think she noticed Chiyo -

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: It's that kimono. (to Chiyo) She remembers how you destroyed it. Now she wants to get even.  78 48

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (askance at Hatsumomo) That sounds less like Mameha and more like another geisha I know.

dialogues.speaker: HATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: (ignoring Mother's jibe) Poor little Chiyo. I fear for you.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: An odd picture, isn’t it? Hatsumomo sweeping into teahouse after teahouse with our little Pumpkin...and Mameha with our maid? Mother & Auntie shake their heads, astonished. Chiyo is paralysed with embarrassment. Mother and Auntie leave.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: I’m so far behind; I will never catch up to you.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPKIN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Chiyo-chan. I will help you.

dialogues.speaker: BATSUMOMO
dialogues.text: Pumpkin! You are never to speak to her again... She. pinches Pumpkin‘s lip hard, and Pumpkin cries out -— HATSUMOMO (cont’d) «..Now you are rivals. Pumpkin gives Chiyo a haunted look, conveying regret and guilt. cUT TO: EXT. MAMEHA’S BEAUTIFUL APT. & SMALL GARDEN COURTYARD. DA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along the Sonogawa, ICICLES melt from the trees, dripping jewel-like droplets. In the foreground sits the Baron‘s impressive automobile. Chiyo hesitates outside Mameha’s apartment, shivering and summoning her courage. She sees: A handsome man, THE BARON (45), emerges from th apartment, with Mameha seeing him out. Chiyo bows humbly:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Konichiwa.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Chiyo is my new protege.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: As lovely as her big sister! And with eyes the color of rain. He gives Chiyo a smile that flusters her. Mameha walks Th Baron to the entrance, Chiyo peeks curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Mameha‘s light-washed, calm apartment:

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: The Baron is a very special man to me; my danna. Someday if you are fortunate, you will have a patron, teo. Don't kneel. You’re not a servant girl anymore. Embarrassed, Chiyo stands before her, head bowed, blushin MAMEHA (cont'd) Step into the light. Chiyo does; Mameha looks into her face. MAMEHA (cont'd) I see water in you.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Does that displease you?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Water‘s powerful. It can wash away earth, put out fire, even destroy iron. But you have not drawn on those strengths, have you? Chiyo shakes her head mutely. Finally she whispers:

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: About your kimono...

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: You may apologize, if you wish. Chiyo drops and bows, her forehead on the mat -  50 MAMEHA (cont ‘d) Why, that is a perfect bow - for a pig farmer. Don’t drop your head. Fingertips together; elbows in. No weight on the hands. Yes. Chiyo accomplishes a correct bow. MAMEHA (cont’d) As for that kimono - I am no fool, Chiyo. Hatsumomo cannot tolerate competition.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: She is jealous of you?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Not me, I’m afraid. (with significance) Someone closer to home. CHIYO blushes. MAMEHA (cont’d) Rise. Not like a horse. Slide your foot forward - that’s it. Now walk. (watching her) You are a magnificent geisha! Mameha walks Chiyo over to the window seat overlooking th stream. They sit. MAMEHA (cont‘d) Tell me, Chiyo, does Mrs. Nitta ever speak of the future?

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: Not to me.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Well, someday soon, she will have to name an heir. One of her own geisha, to succeed her. (leading her) Strange, isn’t it, that she has not adopted Hatsumomo-—

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: And released the tiger from its cage?  80 51 » MAMEHA You have a gift for expression. The Maid brings in a tray; she pours the tea. MAMEHA (cont'd) And if Mrs. Nitta adopts Pumpkin, that is hardly a threat! But a little girl with eyes like rain...

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: But Mrs. Nitta would never choose me.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: On the contrary; that is our goal. Surprised, Chiyo splashes the tea as it is handed to her.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Of course. If you do not inherit the okiya, then we will all be at the tiger’s mercy. Chiyo blows on her tea. Mameha stays her: MAMEHA (cont’d) Water’s always in such a hurry. (smiles) Perhaps it is just as well. We have no time to lose. Mameha takes up her cup, and Chiyo follows. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chiyo undresses at the bath house.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: When does a geisha choose her danna? Mameha is amused and a little offended.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: I‘m afraid it’s the other way around. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 MAMEHA (cont'd) (then) Focus on your studies, Chiyo. Music, the art of conversation. Contrary to popular opinion, that’s the surest way to attract a danna; on your feet...not off them. Carrying their towels to conceal their naked bodies, they step into a tiled room filled with steam.. MAMEHA (cont ’d) Pretend, for example, that I am pouring tea... Mameha sits on a bathing stool, using bathing implements “teapot” and “cup”. MAMEHA (cont‘d) You kneel, just so. You angle the pot low, spout close to the cup, so the aroma does not escape... She mimes pouring. MAMEHA (cont'd) Now here is where you can add a touch of intrigue. Say I’m entertaining the Baron. Like so many clients, he is trapped in an arranged marriage with a woman he does not love. So--in the teahouse, when he is seeking my company instead--I reward him. Like this. She drapes the washcloth like a “kimono sleeve.” MAMEHA (cont'd) With a glimpse of my wrist. Seeing that demure little trace of naked skin...well, it gives him pleasure. As Chiyo practices pouring while holding her “kimono slee MAMEHA (cont’d) When you are sitting down-- (crowding Chiyo) - for the briefest moment, press your leg against his. (when Chiyo starts to giggle) Always by accident, of course! Or, this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 82 53 Mameha tucks up damp tendrils at her nape, demonstrating: MAMEHA (cont'd) Or this: "These little hairs are such a nuisance, always trying to escape.”

dialogues.speaker: ' CHIYO
dialogues.text: (copying) | “These little hairs are such a nuisance..." Laughing, Mameha leads her to the steaming bathing pools:

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. We have leapt from “intermediate” to “advanced” so quickly. You maiko are supposed to be all innocence. (subtly wicked smile) At first. They drop their towels and step into the bath.

dialogues.text: --catches it onstage, in a dance rehearsal 10 MAIKO her o age. She glances down the line of dancers to see Pumpkin. In the audience, Hatsumomo and Mameha watch their fledgli maiko. dialogues.text: Beauty is cruelty.  87 88 89 90 91 55 Chiyo grimaces in protest-- INT. CHIYO’S ROOM. NIGHT. [WINTER] ~ DAY --as Mother replaces her pillow with a wooden stand. She tries in vain to pluck it out Hatsumomo stands in the doorway, laughing--

dialogues.text: --as Hatsumomo and Pumpkin exit, Pumpkin’s coiffure immaculately lacquered, every strand in perfect place. Meanwhile--inside--Mameha shakes her head, sympatheticall the Hairdresser once again draws wax through poor Chiyo's hair-- CLOSE UP: --as a bejeweled ornament slides gracefully int the upswept hair-style of a maiko-- INT. MAMEHA’S APARTMENT. DAY. [WINTER] --colorful maiko kimono festoon the room. Chiyo goes “shopping” among Mameha’s collection. Mameha holds up a beautiful kimono-- CLOSE UP: --and two pale arms slide into a sheer under- kimono--

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: --now dressed in fluttering kimono, Chiyo and Mameha step into the street.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: The fortune-teller suggested November 3rd for your debut-- 87 88 89 90 91  92 56

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) November? Can't it be sooner?

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Sooner? (laughing) Water certainly likes to rush! CLOSE UP: --in quick succession, eight silk bands called are drawn and bound-- MAMEHA (cont'd) You cannot call yourself a true geisha until you can stop a man in his tracks, with a single look. CLOSE UP: --a lavishly embroidered cream kimono closes, l over right--

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: No one can do that. Mameha turns her back to the street:

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Choose someone for me. Chiyo indicates a PASSING MAN who walks absently toward t Mameha takes a few small steps, her eyes downcast. As the Man reaches her, Mameha lifts her eyes to meet his. The M stops, he turns to watch Mameha go. Chiyo, amazed, hurries to catch up with Mameha.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: If I can do that - may I debut sooner? CLOSE UP: A man’s hand yanks the obi strings tight on the back of a geisha’s kimono.

dialogues.speaker: MAMEHA
dialogues.text: Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: CHIYO
dialogues.text: (game now) Go ahead, then. Choose someone for me, Onei-san.  93
